item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit Croatia?

There are not many ex-Communist bloc countries that have so quickly and so radically embraced openness and commerce and tourism like Croatia has. If, when you visit, the scenery and landscape seems familiar, it won't be deja vu - Croatia is the permanent setting for many episodes of the TV series 'Game of Thrones'.

The young, hip population, hordes of travelers and the hedonistic approach to life has Croatia earn the title of the 'New Ibiza'. The weather is excellent for outdoor festivals and music fests with live DJs and international artists are being held increasingly frequently.

The producers of Game of Thrones decided on Croatia because it offers such a wondrous set of sights of every kind. The water of the Adriatic Sea is cerulean blue from afar and crystal clear on close-up. The towering mountains of the Dinaric Alps and verdant forests provide an ethereal landscape within which to lose yourself.

The coastline is dotted with small island, many of which are worth a day trip unto themselves. Croatian beaches are gaining immense popularity for their beauty, serenity and cleanliness. The geography of the land makes it ideal for any number of outdoor sports. Hiking and biking are just ordinary - try your hand at:

  • ziplining;
  • abseiling;
  • rock climbing;
  • white water rafting.

Croatian cuisine is delicious in itself but has been enhanced even further by a dash of cosmopolitan from international restaurateurs. The locally-grown and -produced wine rivals many a top drop from more established countries.

Must See Cities in Croatia

The nation has a rich historical story, something that is communicated by the vast ancient ruins from the Roman and Byzantine eras, as well as medieval ones.

Dubrovnik

Facing the Adriatic Sea, Dubrovnik is renowned for the architecture and distinctive look of its Old Town.

Walking the City Walls has become almost as synonymous with Dubrovnik as the Great Wall of China is in that country. The route gives you fantastic views of the layout and scenery below and beyond and is a great way to get your bearings before you start exploring. For even better views, take the cable car to Mount Srd. A bastion of defense against the Turk invasions, its battlements still stand strong.

Banje Beach is a great place to unwind and people watch whether you are travelling alone or with family or friends. The waters are gorgeous and just nice for most of the year, and the beach is sand, pebble and shingle in parts.

Zagreb

Fancy a look at the aftermath of relationship breakdowns, poignant, hilarious and weird as they may be? Then, you should wander into Zagreb's Museum of broken Relationships. Featuring the remains of ended loves, every component is a donation from a very, very glad or very confused person from around the globe.

The Museum of Contemporary Art is spread across 17,000 square meters and showcases hundreds of modern works of display art. It also features performance art, films and concerts throughout the year.

The unbelievably-green Maksimir Park is great for a stroll.
item.bodyColumn_2:
Split

Croatia's second-largest city is a mix of modern bars and restaurants, and the country's ancient heritage.

UNESCO World Heritage-listed Diocletian's Palace should not be missed. These Roman-era ruins are a mixture of a fort and palace and is Split's biggest attraction. Egyptian sphinxes and columns of exquisite Italian marble grace the sprawling grounds.

St. Dominus Cathedral is one of the most well-preserved remnants of the Roman empire still standing. Its unique octagonal design is surrounded by additions made through the ages - friezes, columns, sculptures and statues that are a wonder to explore.

Flight Characteristics

There are no direct flights from the United State to Croatia, and travelers will need to make at least one stop. From the eastern U.S., the flight time is just under 10 hours if you fly from New York and layover in Frankfurt. This option is provided by Lufthansa.

From the western seaboard, Lufthansa has a flight to Zagreb that also transits through Frankfurt. It takes slightly over 13 hours to land in Croatia after flying from Los Angeles.

item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit Indonesia?

Sprawling across Southeast Asia, Indonesia is a vast nation with innumerable unique experiences waiting to be discovered. While most people associate only the island of Bali with tourism in Indonesia, the country has a wealth of culture, history and natural wonders for a traveler to get lost in.

The name 'Indonesia' originates from 'India' and alludes to the influence from the subcontinent that shaped much of Indonesia's history and culture, and continues to make its presence felt today in everyday life, traditions and the arts.

Some of Indonesia's most important and famous tourist attractions are remnants of this heritage - Central Java's Borobudur, the world's largest Buddhist complex, and UNESCO World Heritage-listed Prambanan Temple are ideal examples.

Indonesia's capacity to absorb a myriad of influences has created a diverse cuisine that runs the gamut of palates. Many dishes that are basically the same and even have the same name can vary significantly, depending on where in Indonesia you sample it, as locals swap ingredients for what is most readily available.

The waters off Indonesia are home to a vast variety of marine life. Scattered across them are pristine dive sites famous the world over for the ethereal window they give of life beneath the waves. If you prefer your action on the waves instead, Indonesia boasts some of Asia's best surfing crests, too.

If wildlife is your thing, unique experiences await you in Indonesia - come face to face with orangutans on Borneo's Kalimantan state and Komodo Dragons on the island of Komodo.

Indonesia is home to 150 volcanoes, the most famous being Mt. Bromo.

Must See Cities in Indonesia

Being so vast, Indonesia has a number of cities that should be on your list to fully understand the diverse nation. Here are a few of the best.

The only Hindu area in the majority-muslim nation, Bali has retained much of its ancient Indian heritage that it shares with the world today. Some of the world’s most beautiful Hindu temples live on in Bali. Uluwatu Temple and Tanah Lot are perfect examples, built on and near the water to add spectacular views to your spiritual journey.

Across, in Chinatown, the beautiful Sam Poo Kong temple dating to the 1400s is a perennial tourist draw. The Great Mosque and Dome Church Blenduk round off the religious diversity here.

  • Bali – technically, Bali is an island, we know. However, there is so much jam-packed into this small area that it earned a place here.
  • Semarang - set on the north coast of Java island, Semarang offers a glimpse back into Indonesia's Dutch colonial heritage. The Dutch East India Company's headquarters was in the massive building complex of Lawang Sewu.
item.bodyColumn_2:
• Yogyakarta - also on Java, Yogyakarta is world-renowned for the Borobudur temple complex and the Prambanan Temple grounds. Visit them and be amazed at how people's beliefs inspired them to create wonderful monuments to their faith using ancient technology.
  • Jakarta – the nation’s capital is home to the Indonesian National Museum (a natural history museum) and the Wayang Museum (which focuses on puppets and dolls used in traditional storytelling).

Flight Characteristics

The U.S. to Indonesia journey is a long one and there are no direct flights available. Many carriers offer a single-stop journey that helps to break up the journey which takes just over 22 hours.

Qatar Airways flies from New York to Jakarta with a layover at their base in Doha. From Los Angeles, the shortest flight is operated by American Airlines. It takes 21 hours and has a layover at Japan's Narita Airport.

item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit Lithuania?

Lithuania? Where is that?

Ahhh, if only they knew. The Republic of Lithuania sits on the Baltic Sea's southeastern shore and offers some of the most affordable getaways in Europe.

Some of Lithuania's most memorable destinations are related to its history of religion. The Hill of Crosses, the Museum of Devils and the Hill of Witches should arouse the interest of anyone interested in understanding the evolution of beliefs.

It is home to the UNESCO World Heritage-listed Curonian Spit, a massive sand dune that keeps the waters of the Curonian and Baltic Seas apart. For those interested, there are three other such sites in Lithuania - the Struve Geodetic Arc, The Kerave Archaeological site and the historic center of the nation's capital, Vilnius.

For architectural history buffs, Lithuania is a wonderland for its neoclassical buildings. For others, Zemaitija National Park's decommissioned Soviet nuclear missile base might be the real draw.

There are other remnants of, and memorials to, the country's tumultuous history. The Museum of Genocide victims and the Vilna Gaon Jewish State Museum attest to the brutality suffered by all Lithuanians and Jewish Lithuanians respectively.

Lithuania has a quirky sense of humor, if a country can have one. You will find trees wearing sweaters, visit the self-declared 'Republic of Uzupis' inside Vilnius and see road signs with smileys and the Mona Lisa. There is also a family park built to resemble a Siberian Soviet concentration camp, complete with statues of communist stalwarts like Stalin and Lenin.

Definitely worth a look.

Must See Cities in Lithuania

Vilnius – the nation’s capital is chock full of surprises for the traveler. From the aforementioned quirky state humor to the most affordable price tags of any European capital, Vilnius definitely entertains on a budget. There are also many interesting places outside the capital:

  • Just outside the capital lies the tragic Paneriai Forest, where countless Jews were murdered. It is a poignant site.
  • The Saint Peter and Paul Church is famous for its collection of over 2,000 statues.
  • Šiauliai - essential viewing, if only for the Hill of Crosses. There are too many thousands of crosses here to count (close to two million by estimates), and added to every day as newlywed couples and pilgrims leave their own. Look closer - many have a story etched into them.
item.bodyColumn_2:
• Trakai - less than 30 km from Vilnius, this city is home to the Trakai Historical National Park. The centerpiece is a beautiful medieval castle in the middle of a blue lake. There are balloon tours to give you the best view. If you venture below, you can cross the footbridge between the lake's islands.
  • Neringa – this seaside resort is home to the Curonian Spit which is worth a visit on its own. However, not far from the Spit is the Hill of Witches, an outdoor sculpture gallery. The subject of this gallery is the nation’s pagan past and features some intricately-created pieces which inspire a combination of intrigue and horror.

Flight Characteristics

There are no direct flights between the United States and Lithuania, and the best option for travelers is a single-stop connecting flight. The fastest of these from New York on the east coast is operated by British Airways. It completes the journey in just over 10 hours, including a layover in Helsinki, Finland.

From the west coast, several airlines offer single-stop trips that transit through various European airports and are exceedingly long. It is probably better to take a domestic flight to New York and board the British Airways flight from there.

item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit Montenegro?

A name which translates into as dramatic a phrase as 'Black Mountain' deserves the personality to match. Here, Montenegro does not disappoint.

Set on the southern coast of Europe, looking out onto the Adriatic Sea, the nation has been at the crossroads of empires and has the history to match. The Venetians, Italians, Turks and the Communists have all had their opportunity to rule and Montenegro has broken free, proud and independent, every time.

It has shed the memories of the Yugoslav upheaval of the 1990s and rebuilt its tourism industry to attract over 1.6 million visitors a year, three times the number of its own population.

The perennial draw of Montenegro is both its natural beauty and its vibrant history. Beautiful sights of water, coast, plains and mountains abound to snare the attention of the romantics. Majestic forts, imposing walled towns, Roman mosaics and ornate Orthodox Christian churches will enthrall history buffs and architecture enthusiasts.

The Montenegrin terrain is an outdoor lover's wonderland, perfect as it is for all manner of activities including hiking, biking, kayaking and horseback riding. The cool forests are still the lairs of wolves and homes of bears.

Montenegro has made a concerted effort to reinvent itself as a cosmopolitan tourism destination with heart. The remnants of its history are well-maintained and carefully preserved while new bars and restaurants are allowed to thrive to appeal more widely to visitors.

Must See Cities in Montenegro

Montenegro can be divided into five regions, each with its own unique draw. Here is a list of one city from each region for a rounded view of the best places to see around the nation:

  • Kotor - the Bay of Kotor has earned itself a spot on the UNESCO World Heritage List for the sites of Perast and Kotor. The latter is exquisite almost without compare but its appeal is more than aesthetic. The Town Walls, River and Sea Gates, St. Tryphon's Cathedral and the maritime Museum of Montenegro are perfect places to discover the heart and soul of this resilient nation.
  • Budva - the central coast's Budva Riviera seems to be modeled on the upscale coastal promenades that are so popular across Western Europe. Budva has garnered immense attention for its thrilling bar and club scene as well as the gorgeous beaches.
  • Podgorica - the capital of the country lies at the southeastern end of the Central Montenegro region and is home to almost a third of the population. The thousand-year old St. George Church, the intriguing architecture of the Holy Heart of Jesus Church and the Millennium Bridge over the Moraca River await.
item.bodyColumn_2:
• Bar - the most interesting destination in the Southern Coast region is the Bar Old Town, which is home to many ancient ruins that speak of the country's history. It is also the location of the world's oldest olive tree, which has been dated to between 2,000 and 2,500 years of age.
  • North Montenegro - this mountainous region is where the winter capital of Zabljak lies on the side of Mount Durmitor. Zabljak is covered in snow for almost four months in a year, making it an ideal winter getaway. When the snow thaws, rafting, mountaineering, cycling and hiking become the activities of choice to take in the amazing scenery.

Flight Characteristics

There are no direct flights from the United States to Montenegro and there will be at least one stop regardless of from where you fly.

The shortest flight time for flights from the east coast are by My Austrian Airlines which completes the journey in 14 hours 30 minutes. From the west coast, the shortest flight time to Montenegro is achieved by Aeroflot which lands there 17 hours after its departure. The stops are at Vienna and Moscow respectively.

item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit Poland?

Who would have thought that Poland is the 16th most visited country in the world?

Yes, this unassuming Eastern European country that sits on the shores of the Baltic Sea is proving itself to be a fantastic tourist destination. Its medieval heritage shines through amazing architecture while its modern persona is on display with its bustling major cities.

Poland was, unfortunately, the setting for many traumatic chapters of the Second World War. The belated silver lining is that the country is committed to remembering the sacrifices of its people and the hardships they underwent through a number of permanently-protected sites that have become immensely popular.

Her clean air, open spaces, good food and wonderful people are all the welcome you need.

Must-See Cities in Poland

Like much of eastern Europe, Poland has a rich heritage of magnificent architecture and monuments. If you are short on exploring time, these two cities should not be missed:

  • Warsaw – Poland’s capital is a patchwork of buildings and monuments from the nation’s rich and turbulent history. Soviet-era minimalist blocks, modern skyscrapers, Gothic churches and neoclassical palaces share the space. The Chopin Museum, POLIN Jewish history museum, remnants of medieval structures and pulsating nightlife all contribute to its eclectic magnetism.
  • Krakow - The biggest draw in Southern Poland, Krakow is built around Rynek Glowny market square that is renowned for its beautiful architecture. The 14th century St. Mary's Basilica and Wieliczka Salt Mine with its underground network of chambers and cathedrals are another major draw. The Auschwitz concentration camp and Oskar Schindler's factory have always attracted legions of visitors.
item.bodyColumn_2:
Flight Characteristics

Okecie Airport is the nation's largest airport and many major international carriers fly there. There are, however, no direct flights from the continental United States to Poland. Several carriers do offer a single-stop flight, usually laying over at France's Charles de Gaulle Airport.

The shortest flight time, including time spent in transit, is 10 hours 25 minutes. This option is offered by the U.S.-based carrier, Delta Airlines.

Air travel on long-distance routes can wear you down, regardless of whether you are traveling for business or pleasure. It can leave you less inclined and less able to enjoy the sights and sounds of your destination.

But if you are flying in a first class or a business class seat, you might not even notice the flight duration. Wider seats with better cushioning and horizontal recline are perfect for the body. Meanwhile, excellent dining options, premium liquors and personalized service pander to your soul.

item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit the U.A.E.?

Not very long ago, the United Arab Emirates was but an insignificant speck in the desert. Revenue from the oil industry has transformed this otherwise parched desert nation of 7 emirates into a global center for tourism.

Tourists love the ever-changing skyline and the continuous array of new wonders that seem to pop up every few months.  No trip to the U.A.E. is ever the same if the developers can help it.

The U.A.E. government is driven and committed in its pursuit of becoming a worldwide hub of business and trade as well as leisure. Many of the world’s largest firms have been lured here by the tax-free incentives the country offers.

Must-See Cities in U.A.E.

There are 3 major cities not to miss:

  • Abu Dhabi – The capital of the U.A.E. is situated in the emirate of Dubai, which is sometimes mistaken for a nation on its own. Abu Dhabi is the site of the world’s tallest building, the Burj Khalifa. The Abu Dhabi Heritage Village offers a great insight into what life was like here before the discovery of oil.
  • Sharjah – Considered the nation’s cultural capital, Sharjah shows off its arab heritage through restored buildings and museums. The Sharjah Aquarium and Blue Souk, which is home to over 600 stores, should be on your itinerary.
  • Fujairah – Fujairah Fort and Fujairah Museum are perennial tourist draws, and the latter houses artifacts from the area’s pre-Islamic era.
item.bodyColumn_2:

Spending many long hours in an aeroplane can seem like a daunting chore, even if you are on the way to the U.A.E. However, where you sit on the plane can turn that chore into an experience that you want to relive over and over.

First class and business class passengers get the very best personalized service, superior dining options (including custom-made creations by renowned chefs), access to the best entertainment and seats that feel more like hotel beds.

Why Visit Sri Lanka?

Situated just off the southern tip of India, this pearl of the Indian Ocean is a largely undiscovered treasure of beauty and experiences. The diverse landscape of this island nation ranges from white sand beaches to humid rainforests to undulating highlands.

Its Buddhist heritage is on display across several ancient ruins dating back millennia. Sri Lanka is a modern, developing nation with much in store for you to discover.

Must-See Cities in Sri Lanka

Colombo – The giant Buddha is the unmistakable indication that you are in the Sri Lanka’s capital. Successive influences – Portuguese, Dutch and British – are evident from its historical architecture. It has:

  • a vibrant nightlife;
  • massive shopping complexes;
  • a skyline of skyscrapers.

Kandy – Situated in central Sri Lanka on a plateau surrounded by tea plantations and rainforests, Kandy is the nation’s religious heart. The Temple of the Tooth, named for its possession of one of the Buddha’s teeth is an iconic pilgrimage site for international visitors.

From exclusive lounges at the airport which offer amenities like massages and enclosed personal waiting areas besides preferred boarding privileges, the luxury of the experience begins even before you step on your plane.

On board, extra-wide seats which recline into beds, large personal entertainment screens, selected fine dining options and superior liquor are all part of the flight experience. Proper cutlery, not flimsy plastic, allow you to savor your meal as it was meant to be enjoyed.

Why Visit Slovenia?

This beautiful central European country is a winter wonderland that is just as gorgeous through all the other months of the year, too. It has developed rapidly in recent years, with modern buildings taking up space beside Renaissance-era ones.

Nature is one of Slovenia’s biggest draws and her scenery from aquamarine lakes to verdant green highlands and white sand beaches combine to make a mosaic of visual treats.

Must-See Cities in Slovenia

Ljubljana – The largest city of Slovenia is also its capital. Ljubljana is not only a pleasure to pronounce but a pleasure to tour, with its vast green spaces and outdoor café culture. Ljubljana Castle is worth a visit, not least for the funicular that visitors can ride up to it.

Bled – This a holiday getaway renowned for its amazingly picturesque scenes of tranquility. It is home to the Triglav National Park which is a winter skiing paradise, and Bled’s island Pilgrimage Church which is accessible only by rowboat.

Why Visit Luxembourg?

This tiny, landlocked western European country is charmingly underdeveloped compared to its neighbors France, Belgium and Germany. It features tight, neat architecture in its capital, also named Luxembourg, and wonderfully green undulating hills almost everywhere else.

A visit to Luxembourg is probably the easiest way to imagine what Europe would be like without the overpopulation, pollution and general chaos.

Must-See Cities in Luxembourg

Tourists tend to visit the following cities:

  • Luxembourg – The Palace of the Grand Duke, dating to the 1500s and the Notre Dame Cathedral with its Gothic architecture should not be missed. Also worth a look are the MUDAM museum of modern art and the American Cemetery which is the last resting place of the famed World War 2 general, George S. Patton, Jr.
  • Esch-sur-Alzette – This is the nation’s second-largest city, with a grand total of less than 35,000 residents. The National Museum of Resistance, dating back to the Second World War, the Lankelz miniature railway, and the nation’s longest shopping strip can all be found here.

With airlines squeezing more seats onto aircraft, it is impossible to find the personal space you require while traveling in economy class.

On the other hand, first class and business class travel is only getting more luxurious as airlines compete for elite clientele who appreciate the finer things in life.

The result is premium class travel that outshines anything that has been offered in the air before. Some carriers offer completely enclosed suites on board which feature beds that are large enough to lie on, spread-eagle.

item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit Israel?

Israel is an enigma; she is the world’s only Jewish state, the site of the origin of religions followed by billions of people across the planet, and a modern, sophisticated society in a neighborhood which does not seem at all conducive to that reality.

Much of the tiny nation’s status as a major tourist destination can be attributed to the fact that its lands are the setting for many of the events of the both the Bible and the Torah. However, apart from religious pilgrimage, Israel is a world center for thought, innovation, creativity and humanity.

It attracts and welcomes people from across the globe that share its philosophy and has a beautifully diverse and energetic population which make every visit to the Holy Land a wonderful experience.

Must-See Cities in Israel

Tel Aviv – The history-rich atmosphere is accentuated by a modern populace that reveres tradition but also loves to party. The Palmach Museum, Diaspora Museum and Tel Aviv Museum of Art can occupy your daytime while its endless stretch of clubs and bars will claim the night.

Jerussalem – The Church of the Holy Sepulchre is the holiest site in Christianity and a destination of pilgrimage for both Christians and inquisitive people the world over. The Yad Vashem memorial to the six million Jews killed in the Holocaust alone is worth spending a day here.

Flight Characteristics

Traveling by air on short-haul flights can be bad enough, but long-haul flights have the tendency to worsen jet lag and leave you unable to enjoy the first day or even days of your dream holiday. Minimize the odds of squandering the wonder of new discovery by choosing to travel in the luxury of first class or business class.
item.bodyColumn_2:
Even though you are on the same plane, travel in premier class means that you will have:

  • access to more personal space;
  • better quality of food and drinks;
  • personalized service.

That, in combination, make for a much better journey.

Seats in first and business class on most airlines are able to lie flat so you can get the rest that you want and be fresh for when you step off the plane at the end of your flight.

item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit Finland?

One of the world’s northernmost countries, Finland is one of the best places to get a glimpse of the amazing Aurora Borealis. Her amazing landscape is largely untouched, a paradise for the nature lover while its fun, hip and friendly people will make you want to keep coming back.

Must-See Cities in Finland

Helsinki – The central avenue of Mannerheimintie is where a lot of the action is in Helsinki – the National Museum which house artifacts from the Stone Age; Kiasma, a modern art museum; and parliament House can all be found here. Temmpeliaukio is a church carved into bedrock that also functions as a concert venue.

Rovaniemi – This one is for the kids – the ‘official’ home of Santa Claus, and it has a toy shop and an igloo hotel. Rovaniemi is also the best places in Finland to view the Northern Lights.

Turku – Turku Castle is also a museum of medieval Finnish history. The Handicrafts Museum harks back to a simpler time before the Industrial Age when so much effort went into every item humans produced.

Flight Characteristics

Many consider the golden age of air travel to be over, gone with the times when terrorism hadn’t cast its shadow and a flight attendant was considered almost as glamorous as a model. However, stiff competition between airlines for premium air travelers is reinventing the experience in ways unimaginable till recently.

item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit Denmark?

Denmark is a remarkable country - it consistently ranks as the world's least corrupt, best educated, most democratic, most prosperous country as well as the one with the best healthcare.

It also holds the honor, dubious or otherwise, of being the world's first country to legalize pornography. In the diametrically opposite direction, Denmark was also home to Hans Christian Andersen, famous for his fairy tales.

Must-See Cities in Denmark

Copenhagen – The capital of Denmark is home to the royal palaces of Amalienborg and Christiansborg as well as the Rosenborg Place which dates back to the Renaissance era. The Tivoli amusement park and Hans Christian Andersen’s ‘Little mermaid’ sculpture are among the must-see sites of the city.

Billund – Billund is home to the Lego head office, largest factory and the first Legoland theme park, which makes it a major attraction for people young and old.

Bornholm – This is an island off the Danish coast that is home to the medieval Hammershus castle, built atop a cliff. Dueodde beach is a popular getaway for Danes and the Bornholm Butterfly Park is ideal for lovers of flora and fauna.

Flight Characteristics

If you have decided that economy class travel is not worth the discomfort when you consider the minimal cost savings, you are on the right track.  First class and business class travel gives you an entirely different experience, both in-flight and before you board.
item.bodyColumn_2:

item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit Bulgaria?

Bulgaria is a Balkan nation of diverse landscapes, one that is developing an increasing modern outlook and the skyline to go with that, while retaining its rich cultural heritage and the monuments and relics that hark to that aspect of her character.

From vast ski fields that provide some of the best winter vacation spots in the region to smooth, wide beaches bordering the aquamarine sea, Bulgaria’s landscape of contrasts is a world waiting to be discovered.

Must-See Cities in Bulgaria

Sofia – This city retains relics of its history of occupation by the Greeks, Romans and Turks. The St. George Rotunda Church built by Romans in the 4th century and the Alexander Nevsky Cathedral which commemorates Russian soldiers killed in the Russo-Turkish War are visitor favorites. The National Archaeological Museum’s Thracian burial mask made of gold is another.

Varna – The Varna Aquarium and nearby Dolphinarium are the biggest draws of this seaside city. For history buffs, the Naval Museum’s Drazki warship which defeated Turkish forces might be the way to spend the day.

Flight Characteristics

There is no doubt that traveling first class or business class affords a far superior experience in every respect when compared to flying coach.

Air travel, particularly on long distance flights can take its toll on both the body and the mind; flying in premier class helps alleviate a lot of the discomfort that can contribute to jet lag and even serious conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
item.bodyColumn_2:
One of the obvious differences is that of seating. First class and business class seats are wider, longer and better cushioned than those in economy. More legroom is available and armrests are wider, creating a wider radius of personal space.

There is a stark difference in the quality of the meals and drinks served; some carriers even offer buffets during certain flights while others allow travelers to book chef-created meals before they board.

item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit Austria?

If you are a connoisseur of classical music, Austria will probably have your unending gratitude for giving the world two of history’s greatest composers, Mozart and Beethoven.

For outdoor sports buffs, its ski fields cater to families, beginner and experts while the glorious summer vistas featured most famously in the classic ‘The Sound of Music’ need no introduction. If you are an automobile fan, there is also the world’s largest Rolls Royce museum to explore.

Must-See Cities in Austria

Vienna – Mozart, Beethoven and Sigmund Freud were all born here. There is an entire Quarter dedicated to the arts, and works from artists both contemporary and classical. The Spanish Riding School’s Lipizzaner stallions are a sight to behold.

Salzburg – The DomQuartier is home to a 17th century cathedral that houses a 4,000-pipe organ. The Renaissance Hellbrunn Palace grounds and the city zoo are tranquil getaways with ample open space and picnic areas.

Flight Characteristics

The luxury of first class and business class travel has to be experienced to be fully appreciated. It is more than just wider seats that become fully-flat beds in the air; it is more than gourmet food and drink while cruising at 30,000 feet; and it is more than access to premium lounges at airports all over the world.

There is no substitute for the personal touch in the care that you enjoy from everyone – ground crew at check-in, lounge staff, and the flight attendants. It is the difference that you feel when you taste a meal in the air that matches one you would find at an elite restaurant.

item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit Hungary?

Who would not want to visit a country with over 1,000 natural hot springs? This sports-mad country is especially good at water polo and there is a national love affair with all things equestrian.

On the other hand, they are also crazy about confectionery and there are countless small businesses in the field that have been run by the same families for many generations, if not centuries. This landlocked nation also boasts an impressive array of neoclassical and medieval architecture to delight sightseers.

Must-See Cities in Hungary

Budapest – This is an amalgamation of two names – Buda and Pest – and refers to the two sides of the Danube River which runs between them. Budapest is the national capital and home to 118 mineral baths. The Budapest History Museum showcases artifacts dating back to the Roman era. The Dohany Street Synagogue Museum and St. Stephen’s Basilica are definitely worth a visit.

Szeged – The Szeged Open Air Festival was first held in 1931 and continues to be celebrated every May. The double spires of the Votive Church, the Ferenc Mora Museum and 330-year old Saint Nicholas Serbian Orthodox Church are a great example of the diversity of Hungary’s architecture as well as historical monuments in their own right.

Eger – Eger was one of the last bastions of the Turks before they were driven out of Europe. Now, the only remnant of that time is a single minaret while the castle of Eger which defended against the invasion. The castle is a well-maintained medieval fortress with an attached history museum.

Flight Characteristics

First class and business class travelers know that there is a world of difference between flying premium class and flying coach.
item.bodyColumn_2:
The better, wider and more comfortable seating is just a small part of the experience - there are also the small touches of attention to detail that make for a truly special experience.

Gold-plated finishing on fittings, the personalized in-flight service where the flight attendants know your name, and complimentary amenities kits designed by renowned fashion houses just add to the mix. The best airlines even offer enclosed suites in first class, where you have a room to yourself for complete privacy.

With the promise of experiences like that, why would you want to deny yourself the pleasure?

item.bodyColumn_1:
Why Visit Czech Republic?

Situated pretty much right in the very center of the European continent, the Czech Republic has been at the crossroads of civilization for a long time and absorbed a little bit of it all into its own character. It is also the perfect launch pad for jaunts to every corner of Europe.

From wines to beers, from tall snowy mountains to deep, gigantic caves, it offers a little of everything to everyone. Cuisine-wise, a visit to the Czech Republic is a reintroduction to almost every conceivable variation of pork and of beer possible.

Must-See Cities in Czech Republic

Prague - The nickname ‘City of a Hundred Spires’ is a testament to Prague’s traditional status as a bastion of Christianity. The Baroque buildings and gothic churches that border the Old Town Square give it a colorful and tranquil serenity. Visit the Old New Synagogue, the world’s oldest active synagogue. Prague Castle, originally built over 1,200 years ago is the seat of power today.

Brno - The Technical Museum focuses on ancient and modern discoveries from basic music machines to complex electron microscopes. Spilberk Castle's museum is worth a visit, as is the Cathedral of St. Peter and Paul.

Karlovy Vary - The abundance of natural thermal springs makes this city a popular destination for visitors from around the country and around the world. The Mill Colonnade is famous for its summer concerts. Czechs love hiking and the Ohre Valley offers a variety of escapades, from the easy to the challenging, in that respect.

Flight Characteristics

There are several direct flights from the United States to the Czech Republic. The shortest of these is the 8 hours 30 minutes it takes to travel from New York’s JFK Airport to Prague.
item.bodyColumn_2:
Spending all those hours cooped up in a plane cabin can be a taxing ordeal… unless you are traveling in first class or business class. Premier class tickets give you access to enhanced service and additional amenities even before you board the plane. Travelers enjoy free lounge access at airports across the world.

On board, extra legroom and wider seats that usually fold completely flat allow you to rest and recuperate in luxury. Personal TV screens, some as large as 23 inches paired with high-quality, noise-cancelling headphones allow you to watch TV shows and movies with audio and visual clarity.

The cuisine selection is above par, with some airlines even opting for inflight buffets or chef-created culinary masterpieces you choose yourself prior to boarding.
